newsitem.title: ITALY: Italian food industry hopeful after black 1996.
newsitem.headline: Italian food industry hopeful after black 1996.

text.p: Italy's food industry is looking for a worry-free 1997 after coming out of one of the worst years the sector has ever seen, Gianfranco Carlone, Chairman of the Italian Federation of Food Industries said on Thursday.

"The Italian food industry has come through a 1996 which can undeniably be defined as the worst year for the country's food industry for a very long time," he told a trade fair in Bari, southeast Italy.
"But we have begun a 1997 which does not give any sign of undue worries," Carlone added.

He said in 1996 the food industry produced 1.4 percent less in quantity terms than in 1995. "This is a heavy drop for a strong, solid, anti-cyclical industry characterised by a rigid demand and which had not recorded similar declines for decades.
"Last year, in fact, Italian families' consumption of food products exceeded 200 trillion lire -- a good figure but one which in constant lire value terms showed a 1.3 percent fall on 1995," he said.
As for exports, whose performance had allowed the industry to enjoy a sort of escape valve up to 1995 and enabled production to grow, "in 1996 this drive completely ran out of steam."

Italian food industry exports last year touched 18.6 trillion lire, a level which in terms of growth barely showed a 2.6 percent increase compared with rates of 10 to 20 percent recorded in previous years, Carlone added.
